text:
233-237, 239-241, 243, 245 Spring Street, north side, adjoining and west of the Butterick Building at the N.W. corner of Macdougal Street (future N.W. corner of Sixth Avenue). These old houses will all be demolished in the winter 1925-26 to make room for the new Vivadon Building. With the exception of the 239 half of No. 239-241, they are all frame houses faced with brick. 1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Clark Street, south from Spring to Broome Streets. This two-block street will be absorbed by the extension of Sixth Avenue; and its west side, shown at the right, will become part of the west side of Sixth Avenue. Public School No. 38, shown here on the south side from Dominick to Broome Streets, will become 141-131 Sixth Avenue (new number).

1926.

Macdougal Street, north from the eastern end of the westernmost section (originally Brannon Street) of Spring Street (q.v.). This is the real beginning of Macdougal Street, although during the southward extension of Sixth Avenue (1927-1930) the latter will absorb the first two blocks of it. The Butterick Building, built in the winter of 1902-1903 as 1 Macdougal Street or 223-221 Spring Street, will become the N.W. corner of Sixth Avenue and Spring Street. Nos. 20 to 34 Macdougal Street, on the east side from Van Dam Street to Prince Street, will become 186 to 204 Sixth Avenue, and Nos. 2 to 18 and 9 to 35 Macdougal Street will be demolished. At the right of this picture, you can see the frame side of 219 Spring Street, which, with its neighbors 217 and 215 Spring Street, two similar brick-faced houses, is directly in the path of Sixth Avenue Extension. No. 2 Macdougal Street is the first five-story tenement house at the right, adjoining 219 Spring Street. Between No. 4 and No. 8 (the two-story stable) there is a short alley at right angles to the street. Macdougal Street is the seventh of a set of streets laid out west of and parallel to Broadway. After the end of the American Revolution they were renamed in honor of various Generals in the successful war for independence.

1926.

Spring Street, east from Macdougal Street, showing part of the old frame house at the corner, No. 219 Spring Street, which will be demolished next year when Sixth Avenue Extension is cut through. The bend in Spring Street at this point marks the junction of the original Spring Street, on which we are looking east, with the western section, which was originally laid out as Brannon Street, but given to Spring Street before 1811.
1926.

Spring Street, western section (originally Brannon Street), west from and including the future Sixth Avenue Extension (Clark Street on the south side, and Macdougal Street on the north side). The Butterick Building, erected in the winter 1902-03, at the right, will become the N.W. corner of Sixth Avenue and Spring Street. Adjoining the Butterick Building, and opposite the northern end of Clark Street (which will become part of the west side of Sixth Avenue), the new Vivadou Building is under construction (see also Vandam Street). At the southwest corner of Varick Street may be seen part of the American News Building, built two or three years before this picture was taken. The absorbtion of Brannon Street by Spring Street took place about 1807, and is one of the earliest examples of a process which went on in the city's street nomenclature all through the Nineteenth Century. "The Villager" attributes the name Brannon to the family of a man of that name who kept a public house in this neighborhood up to 1861.

1926.

(1)
Sixth Avenue, looking southwards from the Butterick building located at corner of Spring and Mac Dougal Streets.

(2)
East side of Sixth Avenue looking south from Clarke Street, north from Dominick Street.

(3)
Sixth Avenue, southeast corner of Walker and West Broadway looking across demolition for extension of Sixth Avenue el.

P.L.Speer.
October 19, 1928.

text:
(1)
Sixth Avenue, north from Spring Street.
October 11, 1928.
P.L.Sperr, Photographer.
title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - Spring Street.

text:
Alley between 4 and 8 Macdougal Street, east side, and the view north from it inside the block between Macdougal and Sullivan Streets, north of Spring Street, during the reconstruction of the southern end of Macdougal Street as part of Sixth Avenue Extension. In the center of the block is a 5-story inside tenement house at the rear of what used to be the 4-story house at 14 Macdougal Street. To the right may be seen the rear of 104 and 102 Sullivan Street, and, more to the right, part of the rear of the old 6-story stables at 96-100 Sullivan, with its little 2 story wing in the rear. The south side of this old stable exactly marks the old boundary line between the Trinity Church Farm and the West Bayard Farm.

P. L. Sperr.

October 17, 1928.
